ygData.subject: Re: about number of genes

It is definitely not a good policy to start with a very large number of gen=
es and prune down.  That means starting in a very high-dimensional search s=
pace for no principled reason, which means search gets off to a very slow s=
tart.  However, the idea that you start small and go through phases of addi=
ng genes and deleting them is reasonable and has been shown effective by so=
me on this group, like Colin Green and Derek James. 

ken

--- In neat@yaho=
ogroups.com, "Nikolai" <ker_31_toluca@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
> just watched th=
is video about human genes:
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Dyr428fhp64I
=
> 
> it says that:
> an amoeba has 4,000,000 genes
> a grain of rice has ar=
ound 40,000 - 50,000 genes
> and a human genome has around 25,000 genes.
> =

> also i have found (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Junk_DNA/) that 95% of g=
enes in human genome are junk (like disabled genes in NEAT?) 
> So, a worth=
ful ammount of gene in a genome would be around 1,250 genes?
> 
> How it is=
 possible, that a complex specie like human being has so little genes and a=
 prehistoric amoeba has so many genes? 
> The only conclusion i can make fr=
om here, is that instead of starting from a null genome and increase the nu=
mber of genes we should start with a lot of random genes and work on method=
s to reduce the number of genes while conserving the same(or increasing) fi=
tness.
> Or, we should start with null genome and grow the genome until the=
 fitness stops improving, and then work on optimization of the genome until=
 genome is reduced in size, when genome is not reduced anymore, we should s=
tart adding genes again.
> 
> Just an idea.
>
